newsitem.title: HUNGARY: Pope's health at centre stage in Hungary trip.
newsitem.headline: Pope's health at centre stage in Hungary trip.

text.p: Pope John Paul's health was the focus of attention on Saturday during a visit to Hungary in which he sought to promote a post-communist spiritual revival in eastern Europe.

His trip, to mark the 1,000th anniversary of a monastery at Pannonhalma, near Gyor, was the first since hospital tests following an abdominal infection in mid-August raised renewed concern for his health.
The 76-year-old Pope has appeared fatigued during the trip and had to brave a bitingly cold wind at an open-air mass for an estimated 130,000 people on Saturday, final day of his two-day visit.

"The tests in August didn't find out the source of the infections or whether they were the same infection or whether they will recur," Joaquin Navarro-Valls, the Pope's chief spokesman, told reporters after the mass at a briefing dominated by questions about the Roman Catholic leader's health.
"I have no interest in demonstrating that the Pope is a superman," said Navarro-Valls, who is a doctor himself.

He said, however, that the Pope "basically...remains a healthy man" and had no plans to stop the foreign travel that has been the hallmark of his papacy. A four-day trip to France is scheduled for later this month.

Following the briefing, Navarro-Valls amplified on his remarks, telling reporters, "As a personal opinion, a hypothesis that could explain what is going on in the field of the infection is that it could be some intestinal weakness left from the first operation in 1981."
The Pope survived a 1981 assassination attempt when he was shot in the abdomen in St Peter's Square.
Poor health in recent years, including surgery to remove a colon tumour in 1992, has fired speculation about the Pope's condition and unconfirmed reports of serious illness.
Following the mass, the Pope met all 20 members of the Hungarian Bishops' Conference, who said afterwards that the Pontiff had appeared to be in good health.

"He seemed to be in pretty good health and full of energy," said Istvan Seregely, Archbishop of Eger and chairman of the bishops' conference, which held its meeting with the Pope in the 16th century bishop's palace of this western Hungarian city.

Bishop Asztrik Varszegi, Arch Abbot of the Pannonhalma Monastery where the Pope presided at vespers on Friday, said he wanted to dispel "rumours" that the Pope had felt faint and was too tired to read his homily, and a monk had to read it for him.
"The Holy Father started the address in Hungarian but as originally conducted there was a Hungarian reader and sometimes the Holy Father read some sections in Hungarian," Varszegi said.
The Pope in his mass and later remarks pressed Hungarian and East European Catholics to undertake a post-communist spiritual revival.

"Do not be discouraged by economic and social difficulties, by unemployment, by widespread poverty, by the decline of moral values in the generation which grew up without religion," the Pope said at the mass where people wore heavy winter coats and wrapped themselves in blankets to stay warm.
The Pope later urged the bishops "above all (to) be defenders of human life".

"Nowadays a consumerist and hedonistic society especially threatens life which is not yet born and that which is reaching its end," the Pope said. "It is the duty of believers to promote the values of life and to defend life in word and action."
